instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01041: What is 820-01041? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.ISL9240: What is ISL9240? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2018 through 2020.
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.3V3_G3H: What is 3V3_G3H? This is one of the first power rails that must turn on for Macbooks that use USB-C for charging. This power rail powers the CD3215 chip that controls the USB-C charger, speaks to the USB-C charger, and requests 20 volts up from the default 5 volts that the USB-C charger puts out when initially connected to an unknown device. .
definitions.C7050: What is C7050? Capacitor between current sense lines on ISL6259 chip for battery current sensing, you should measure around 2.202 ohms across this. Often when the resistance across this capacitor is higher it is because one of the current sense resistors going to the ISL6259 chip has failed. When current sensing resistors between the shunt resistor and the ISL6259 power IC have failed the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being sent to or drawn from the battery, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing/sending power to the battery as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H, quarter fan spin, boot looping, or battery not charging..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-07 5v on charger
threads.message: I've got an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-07 on the bench that pulls 4.89v 35mA. Board is immaculate, no liquid anywhere and all indicators are still white. PPBUS is 3.74v, checked for  <SIGNAL>CHGR_EN_MVR</SIGNAL> and it is missing. Is there anything else to check before suspecting the <CHIP>ISL9240</CHIP>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-07 5v on charger
threads.message:
<CHIP>U7000</CHIP> is the first suspect.
But should take some diode mode readings and voltages around it.
Check its basic voltages; <SIGNAL>P_IN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>AUX_DET</SIGNAL>, VDDA/P.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-07 5v on charger
threads.message: Checked those voltages, I get 3.78v on VDDA, 4.68v on VDDP, 4.8v on <SIGNAL>P_IN</SIGNAL>, and 1.21v on <SIGNAL>AUX_DET</SIGNAL>. Apologies if this is a stupid question, but I've never troubleshooted around this area of the board before, what lines should I check with diode mode and what sort of values am I looking for? I wish I had another working model of this board to compare to.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-07 5v on charger
threads.message:
"I get 3.78v on VDDA, 4.68v on VDDP"
There is a big difference, change <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>.

Diode mode on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> are dirst to check, if missing these voltages.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-07 5v on charger
threads.message: Will change <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>. Is it safe to assume that most everything on Aliexpress doesn't have firmware and won't work? Otherwise I'll have to pick up a battery case as a donor.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-07 5v on charger
threads.message:
Real new <CHIP>ISL9240</CHIP> is not available; do not trust chinese sellers.
It is Apple proprietary chip, Intersil cannot sale it to anyone else.

Buying removed chips can't assure the quality.
You can try getting 5-10 in the same order; maybe half of them are good.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-07 5v on charger
threads.message: Forgot I had a recycled board with an <CHIP>ISL9240</CHIP>, used that for the swap and I now get 4.95v 0.01a. VDDA and VDDP of the new <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> are 4.95v, <SIGNAL>P_IN</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>AUX_DET</SIGNAL> are the same.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-07 5v on charger
threads.message: What about F7000 voltage now?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-07 5v on charger
threads.message: Hmm, F7000 is 0v now. Diode mode says 0.103 with red probe on ground

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-07 5v on charger
threads.message: Sorry, F7000 is actually 0.927v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-07 5v on charger
threads.message: Diode mode to ground on both directions?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-07 5v on charger
threads.message: Looks like the same diode mode reading of 0.103 on either side of F7000.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-07 5v on charger
threads.message: I said in both DIRECTIONS; red and also balck probe at ground!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-07 5v on charger
threads.message: Sorry about that. Just checked with red as ground and then black as ground, both give 0.103

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-07 5v on charger
threads.message: Please check in diode mode, not ohm scale...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-07 5v on charger
threads.message: I just measured again and double checked that I am in diode mode. I'm now getting 0.770 with the red probe as ground, and 0.910 with the black probve as ground.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-07 5v on charger
threads.message: Now check if you get the same readings in any big coil.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-07 5v on charger
threads.message: No big coils have the same reading

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-07 5v on charger
threads.message: Remove F7000/1 and check <CAPACITOR>C7050</CAPACITOR> voltage.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-07 5v on charger
threads.message: Looks like with both F7000/1 removed <CAPACITOR>C7050</CAPACITOR> is at 12.27v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-07 5v on charger
threads.message:
So you have a problem on the <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> side, after the fuses.

Set the multimeter on buzzer/diode mode and fix one probe at <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>.
Then check if buzzes touching every coil with the other probe.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-07 5v on charger
threads.message: At L7231 I get 0.108 in diode mode and the meter beeps. I take it that's not a good thing...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-07 5v on charger
threads.message:
Do you have 0.108 to ground at L7231?
Or between L7231 and <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-07 5v on charger
threads.message: Sorry, should have clarified. I have 0.108 between L7231 and <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-07 5v on charger
threads.message:
I said to find one coil with 0 ohm in such reading, if possible.
If none, is more difficult to diagnose, because any chip connected to <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is suspect; don't exclude a cap also.
